html: 1.6.25  1:38 am   how do i increase my productivity while sitting in my bedroom working on my computer? i guess the only REALLY rigid requirement is that i still need to access my computer for the projects i'm working on, but it just feels too laid back and unstructured and i can do whatever, access whatever, and i end up spending houuuuurs not working or doing anything remotely productive towards my goals. thoughts? does going to work in a public space (library) help, or maybe just locking my computer down so much that i can't access anything? i feel like i need to trick myself into being productive, because it's the only way i've ever managed to do it before (tricking myself into believing a schedule has actual pressure, tricking myself into using todo lists, etc). the problem is that my brain will 100% of the time EVENTUALLY see through the trick, and it'll stop working. so i feel like i need something material. it feels pretty grim, though, because i've been having this issue for literal years now, and my life is just ticking on by. so..... if you've got any advice it'd be much appreciated. thanks

html:
1.5.25  5:52 am   Are you the kind of person to make a new year's resolution?

e.............. think
embedded answer: https://billwurtz.com/questions/newyearsresolution.html


1.3.24  3:27 am   Got any New Year's resolutions?

      i prefer real resolutions instead. i still have several of them going, including a major one from last march and another one from last may

12.30.23  1:14 pm   What's your New Year's resolution?

      to make my resolutions at all other times except new years, which fortunately i don't have to do now because i already did it another time

12.28.23  11:21 pm   What are your New Year's resolutions?

      would seem fake, if i made them. new years resolutions strike me as more of a december/january conversation piece than an actual commitment to anything

12.3.23  9:32 am   any new years resolutions?

      start adding "for 2024" to everything

1.1.23  1:11 pm   do you have a new years resolution

      no, but i have resolutions most other times

1.1.23  10:19 am   What's your opinion on new year's resolutions

      fake

1.1.23  12:13 am   What's your new year resolution for 2023

      to start adding "for 2024" at the end of all my video titles next december

12.31.22  12:41 pm   Happy new year, Bill. What's your new year's resolution?

      any goal i make that's not on new years. because new years resolutions are famous for being fake things that people only think about in the new year season. so to counteract this, i use the phrase 'new years resolution' to refer to any goal i have at any time EXCEPT for the new years season, because during the new years season it might get misconstrewed for one of the fake ones

10.29.22  6:53 pm   I'm thinking of starting to ask a question here every day, but I'm wondering if I should wait until january 1st to start it as a new year's resolution. what do you think?

      that depends whether you want it to fail

1.1.21  7:32 pm   What is your new years resolution

      i don't make resolutions for new years. i just make them whenever i need them

11.23.20  12:54 pm   How do I become more normal?

      how about making a new years resolution and then giving up on it somewhere around january 9th

1.29.20  12:08 am   what new years resolution has already failed?

     the one where it's supposed to be january 1st for the entire year

1.27.20  12:23 am   Do you make new year's resolutions

     maybe if i wanted it to fail

1.19.20  3:05 pm   why don't you answer your questions

     it's part of my new years resolution. do not answer any questions. that's what the resolution says

1.5.20  5:06 pm   i forgot to make new years resolutions. 

     new years resolutions are usually fake anyway. the good news is you can make resolutions at any time, which could potentially be much more real and last longer

1.3.20  7:46 pm   did you make a new years resolution

     no way, those ones fail. must make resolutions independently of new years. unless you want it to fail, in that case definitely a new years resolution is the way to go, you will forget all about it by jan 6

1.3.20  12:36 am   new year's day feels so great and motivating and like a refresh that i have been desperately craving for months. how do i achieve that start over/clean slate/kick in the ass/time to start doing things feeling without having to wait all those months?

     this might not be what you want to hear, but i always achieve the best results when i do it at my own original time, not jan 1. jan 1st seems jinxed for failure. honestly have you ever met anyone who was still doing their new years resolution in august

12.31.19  3:39 pm   What's your New Year Resolution of the decade?

     that might not be the best way to make resolutions

12.31.19  12:15 am   what are your new year's resolutions

     none. those ones fail. must make resolutions independently of new years. unless you want it to fail, in that case definitely a new years resolution is the way to go, you will forget all about it by jan 6

12.30.19  7:31 pm   What's your New Years resolution? (Example: learn how to milk a cow)

     new year's resolutions are famous for failure. so when i make resolutions i am very careful to make sure that they have nothing to do with new years

12.29.19  3:36 pm   do you ever make new years resolutions?

     maybe if i wanted it to fail

12.27.19  12:14 pm   wait but what if i resolve to do something independent of new year's but it just so happens to correlate with new year's?

     that should be fine

      will that trick my brain into letting it be a dumb stupid failure?

     as long as you don't call it a new years resolution

      should i wait?

     you must do it when the time seems exactly right

      or will i lose the energy if i wait until mid jan or feb? or maybe start on that shit asap before it becomes new year's so it's not a new year's resolution?

     no need to avoid jan 1 nor gravitate toward it

      have you ever had an important shift that coincidentally lined up with the new year,

     yes

      or perhaps intentionally?

     absolutely not

      new year new year's new year new year's new year new year's year years and year's

     

12.25.19  8:55 pm   what are your resolutins for new years?

     none. those ones fail. must make resolutions independently of new years. unless you want it to fail, in that case definitely a new years resolution is the way to go, you will forget all about it by jan 6

12.25.19  1:28 am   What's your new year's resolution for 2020?

     new year's resolutions are so infamous for failure, i very meticulously make sure that my resolutions have no connection to 'new years'

12.21.19  10:56 pm   thinking about making a new decade reaolution, any suggestions?

     cursed. even worse than new years resolutions. if you want to make a resolution, i am begging you, please make sure it is not related to the beginning of any calendar period. unless you would prefer it to fail

12.19.19  8:02 pm   what's your new year's resolution?

     new year's resolutions are famous for failure. so when i make resolutions i am very careful to make sure that they have nothing to do with new years

12.17.19  11:47 pm   What are your New Year's resolutions for 2020?

     i don't make resolutions for new years. i just make resolutions whenever i need to, without checking to see if it's new years

     on august 23, 2018, i made a resolution to release music videos every 14 days without fail

     i don't make resosolutions for new years. i just make resolutions whenever i need to, without checking to see if it's new years

html:
1.5.25  1:11 am   a couple years ago i distinctly remember reading = a response on here that went something along the lines of "use as few chords as possible when writing a song"

     --i've been haunted by this ever since.

      the more i dig into your music, the more i realize just how much of it is founded on the most rudimentary I's, IV's, and V's, despite all the crazy fills and modulations.

      when i write, i often find myself getting distracted by the more lush and colorful sound of upper extensions,

      as well as lots of dramatic chord movements.

      i've trained my brain to prioritize those kinds of sounds, and it feels like anything else sounds, regrettably, "plain". but i feel oftentimes that it undermines my music in the grand scale of things; i'd do ANYTHING to go back in time to before i was so mired in jazz theory.

      do you have any advice on achieving this sort of "harmony nirvana" that you seem to have? it's as if you know perfectly where to place all the surprising and exciting harmonic moments without compromising simplicity.

     tl;dr: as a theory-obsessed berklee dropout, how can i learn the confidence to use more "basic" or "boring" chords in my music?
original_html:
1.5.25  1:11 am   a couple years ago i distinctly remember reading = a response on here that went something along the lines of "use as few chords as possible when writing a song"

     --i've been haunted by this ever since.

      the more i dig into your music, the more i realize just how much of it is founded on the most rudimentary I's, IV's, and V's, despite all the crazy fills and modulations.

      when i write, i often find myself getting distracted by the more lush and colorful sound of upper extensions,

      as well as lots of dramatic chord movements.

      i've trained my brain to prioritize those kinds of sounds, and it feels like anything else sounds, regrettably, "plain". but i feel oftentimes that it undermines my music in the grand scale of things; i'd do ANYTHING to go back in time to before i was so mired in jazz theory.

      do you have any advice on achieving this sort of "harmony nirvana" that you seem to have? it's as if you know perfectly where to place all the surprising and exciting harmonic moments without compromising simplicity.

     tl;dr: as a theory-obsessed berklee dropout, how can i learn the confidence to use more "basic" or "boring" chords in my music?

html: 1.4.25  7:11 pm   Decided on a whim today to take a different path than I normally do on a walk. When I went down it I kept thinking to myself "Why don't I go down here? Why haven't I incorporated this into my normal route yet? This is nice." It got me wondering why people get so stuck in a routine or become reluctant to try different things. Even when those things are relatively easy to try. Have you ever experienced that?
